subject: Creativity
title: Subtext in Character: What People Don't Say
description: A 1-minute de-risking session on Subtext in Character: What People Don't Say.

hook.text: In real life, people rarely say what they mean. In great fiction, characters don't either. The gap is called subtext.

buildup.text: A character says 'I'm fine.' They're clearly not. The reader sees the truth behind the words â€” and feels the tension of.

discovery.text: Harold Pinter mastered this â€” his plays are full of pauses, deflections, and unsaid feelings.

twist.text: Subtext requires trust in the reader. Beginning writers over-explain.

climax.text: In Brokeback Mountain, 'I wish I knew how to quit you' says everything about forbidden love without ever naming it.

punchline.text: The most powerful writing happens between the lines.
